I get a bit tongue-tied talking about Hitchcock's greatest movies because they are just so remarkable, so astonishing, so entertaining, so multi-levelled, that it's very difficult to put into words what makes them great. Hitchcock made some of the greatest movies ever made, and 'Vertigo', though by no means his most accessible film, is quite possibly his crowning achievement. It is without any doubt a masterpiece, and I cannot fault it in any way. Every time I watch it I am knocked out, and every time I see something new, some nuance or moment that I appreciate more than I did the previous viewing. Jimmy Stewart, one of the most popular movie star in Hollywood history, gives a remarkable performance throughout, one of the best in his career. Stewart had worked with Hitchcock before, and had always been superb, especially in the much copied suspense classic 'Rear Window' a few years prior to this, but he plays against type in 'Vertigo' and is jaw-droppingly good. It's difficult to remember now that 'Vertigo' is regarded as a movie milestone, that it received many bad reviews when it was originally released, and was a relative failure for Hitchcock. A lot of this had to do with Stewart's intense performance I think, and also the difficult subject matter. 'Vertigo' is essentially a tale of sexual obsession, something most people were probably not expecting at the time! Almost as good as Stewart is Kim Novak ('The Man With The Golden Arm') in a role that she will always be remembered for. 'Vertigo' is a virtuoso piece from Hitchcock, and a movie that will no doubt continue to inspire other film makers over the years to come. However the most important thing about it is that it is still wonderful viewing, and a movie experience that you will never forget. In my mind it is one of the three of four greatest American movies. Simply astonishing.

Alfred Hithcock's "Vertigo" undoubtedly deserves its status as one of Hitch's best movies and one of Hollywood's most important movies. It is still today haunting, mysterious and sometimes poignant.
At its core, the movie is a love story - the tale of a man obsessed with a woman. The man is James Stewart in a great performance as San Francisco police detective John "Scottie" Ferguson (James Stewart) who retired after realizing he has acrophobia (fear of heights, which of course will serve as the foundation of some of the movie's memorable scenes) that led to the accidental death of a partner while saving him. He meets an old, now-rich acquaintance Gavin Elster (Tom Helmore) who hires Scottie as a private eye to keep an eye on his wife Madeline (Kim Novak) who is acting peculiarly and her husband believes she is haunted by a ghost from the past. As he follows her, it is clear the beautiful Madeline is enthralled by a long-dead woman called Carlotta Valdes (she visits her grave, stares at a museum portrait of her and checks into an old hotel under her name). When she drowns herself and he saves her, Scottie starts to draw nearer to and fall for his subject. 
The love story and obsession elements of "Vertigo" sometimes overtake the mystery element (the plot twist is actually revealed two-thirds into the movie) but despite that, the movie never loses its haunting and thrilling feel. Stewart delivers a landmark performance as an old lonely man who grows overtly obsessed with this woman. But it is Novak who is a real revelation as she excellently delivers on a somewhat difficult and challenging role (dhe actually plays two characters in the movie but I won't reveal more on that). Barbara Bel Geddes is also good as Midge, the fun friend and confidante of Scottie who has a soft spot for him. 
The film was adapted to the screen by Alec Coppel and Samuel A. Taylor, based on the French crime fiction novel The Living and the Dead (D'entre les morts) by Pierre Boileau and Thomas Narcejac, and the movie does have some of the poise of the greatest European movies. The San Francisco setting really helps. Hitchcock's takes audiences on a tour across the city (mostly filmed on location) and many of the important landmarks will last in one's memory as they served as the setting of some of the movie's more beautiful scenes from the Golden Gate Bridge to the Mission San Juan Bautista on the outskirts, which is the setting for the famous bell tower scenes (worth noting, the tower was destroyed long before the shooting and had to be matted in with a painting using visual effects). Long time Hitchcock collaborator Bernard Herrmann delivers a haunting, perfectly suiting score that is one of the most memorable in cinema history. "Vertigo" is definitely one movie that will stay with you long after you have seen it. Nominated for Two Oscars: Art Direction/Set Decoration, Sound.

The working title for this classic ("Darkling I Listen"), taken from Keats' "Ode to a Nightingale", may well have proved just as riveting, though longer when compared, as Vertigo itself. Keats' obsession with the nightingale, as a means of escapism from madness, is itself comparable to Scottie's fragile love for Madeleine. But while Keats and Scottie both experience madness, their means of escapism are towards two different ends: the one towards a sort of Platonic Love for the Idea of Nature, the other towards Erotic Love for a woman who never really was - obsession at its finest. Which explains why the film's title - Vertigo - may well have been Hitchcock's best decision with regards to his greatest work.

Critics and viewers alike today rank the usual things - Stewart's and Novak's non-Oscar nominated performances that are among the finest in film history, music that resonates with perhaps the most fabulous work of obsession (Tristan and Isolde), Saul Bass' opening titles that grab us from our seats, and last but not least, the surprise ending that would have compelled the AFI to rank this as the greatest mystery thriller ever concocted - individually and independently. But in my firm opinion, it is the mix of these elements (like every great film) and the sum of its exquisite parts - Stewart's and Novak's performances, Herrmann's music, Bass' titles and so on - that give light to this masterpiece that still, after all these years, surpasses the expectations of many a film critic in 1958, who ranked this gemstone in an undeserving low-end position. This is artistic genius expressed in the biggest and greatest apotheosis in the history of cinema - Vertigo.

In Vertigo Hitchcock explores the idolatry of the image and very concept of desire. While perhaps not as formally daring as Psycho or as iconic as Rear Window, Vertigo can reasonably lay claim to being Hitchcock's masterpiece. "Scottie" Ferguson's obsession with Madeleine constitutes him as an ideal spectator, underlining the ways in which desires can be shaped without our even realizing it. He becomes both victim and villain, creating both sympathy and revulsion as he reveals the potential perversity of film viewing and what happens when we fall in love with an image rather than a flesh and blood human being. In the end, isn't Scottie's desire to remake Judy into his ideal of Madeleine merely the obsessive film fan's desire for the repetition that cinema offers? Furthermore, such themes only scratch the surface of what Vertigo has to offer, all while wrapped up in a moving, visually stunning picture. Perhaps this explains why so many directors and cinephiles return again and again to Vertigo. I know that I will.

"Vertigo" is a 1958 film directed by Alfred Hitchcock. A film about obsession. I would put it among the 5 greatest films ever made. I must confess here, that this blog is also inspired by this film. The showman of popular cinema, Mr. Hitchcock directed a remarkable sequence of films in a row, each of them a classic; Vertigo (1958), North by Northwest (1959), Psycho (1960) and The Birds (1963). Never has a director made four such genuinely great movies in such a short space of time, either before or since. The pick of this high standard bunch is undoubtedly Vertigo. From the opening titles, with their circling spiral imagery, to the dramatic final scene this is a movie that takes you to a different time and place.

Talking too much about "Vertigo" is not a good idea. There's too many obvious spoilers in recounting the plot of the film. "Vertigo" is a uniquely personal film, not only for Hitchcock, but for a broad array of viewers who, like me have latched onto its tragic story.

My favorite scene?

Well... There are many actually. A particular scene with mesmerizing camerawork is when James Stewart(Scottie) and Kim Novak hug. We see from Scottie's point of view- the ghostly figure appears in the eerie green-tinged neon light reflected from the hotel sign outside the window. Her metaphysical, spiritual figure assumes solid shape as she moves out of the ghostly green light and crosses the floor to him, to embrace and kiss passionately. The camera pans and swirls around them (their background surroundings dissolve and place them in the livery stable in Scottie's subjective imagination, a location very important to the film)- the sensation must be the same distorted but gratified feelings Scottie is experiencing- vertigo. Completely lost in the dream, overlapping fantasy and reality, the loving couple continue kissing in front of the pale, greenish haze of the window. Also the definitive dolly zoom effect (the camera is pulled away from a subject whilst the lens zooms in to create the "falling-away-from-oneself feeling") on the staircase of the bell tower to create the vertigo dizziness.

This is one of Hitchcock's most famous works and deservedly so. Hitchcock is the king of suspense and this film brilliantly shows why that is so. He leads you into thinking the story is over when Stewart ends up in a mental institution, but it's only then when it starts unfolding. Kim Novak has a radiance similar to Grace Kelly, her appearance is just as regal and attention-commanding, but there's something oddly dry in her acting in comparison to Kelly. Stewart does his best work in the film when he confronts Novak with her compliance in the murder plot, he's the embodiment of authority, even though Novak seems to break like a porcelain figurine in his firm grab.      Vertigo is most definitely the best film about acrophobia ever made. You can center your plot on the fear itself or even place the infamous phobia as the films villain. But Ill tell you what. You will NEVER get close to matching Vertigo in overall perfection and grace. This is an intellectually masterful film thats full of surprises. From unique visuals to wonderful performances, this film is without question flawless. Its got style, romance, drama, mystery, and the unbeatable suspense that only Alfred Hitchcock can deliver. Not only is it a great mystery, but it challenges the mind in ways that I will never truly know. Watching Vertigo may as well be the cinematic equivalent to the very feeling of an acid trip (although one which you can control). At times, things can be visually sublime in appearance, although its steady and always under control none the less. Hitchcock didnt write this beauty, although whoever did should by all means be proud. The style of narrative is so complex and rich that it may not appeal to those of this current generation. The world is no longer ready for films such as this, and therefore only true film buffs can remember the greatness that is a Hitchcock film. With that being said, I can only recommend Vertigo to those who enjoy thinking and the philosophy of a film. Those with simple minds will be bored as hell with this one, so therefore it may not appeal to everyones liking. But believe me when I say that its a piece of art, and nobody can deny that. And if someone does, then they are being pretentious and obviously confused. Like I said, the world is no longer ready for films with such content as this one. Cinema has become rather commonly simplistic nowadays, and Vertigo reminds me that there were once many, many geniuses working in the film industry. There are indeed some still working today, but back then there was more. And Hitchcock was the one to influence a generation of filmmakers. And if you watch ANY mystery of the modern generation, youll notice a little Hitchcock in every one.

              John Scottie Ferguson is an acrophobic retired police officer. He often visits his friend Midge, who provides her communication services in an attempt to make John a tad happier. So one day, an old friend from college asks John to work as a private investigator that will follow his wife and study her recently strange behavior. John accepts after a bit of persuasion, but proceeds with caution. He develops feelings for the mans wife (whos name is Madeline), although looses her all too easily. He rescues her from drowning in the bay and takes her in to his home, only to have her commit suicide by jumping off the local church roof. Heartbroken and full of anxiety, John decides to lay low for a while. Sadly, hes having a lot of trouble forgetting his dear Madeline, and ultimately begins to feel as if hes seeing her everywhere. Well, it is as they say: We see what we want to see. But one day, he meets her again mysteriously. This new girl bears the name of Judy, and John starts to develop strong romantic feelings for her as well. Since I dont want to spoil the twists and surprises in store, Im not going to go any further. While it may seem simplistic at first, Vertigo never fails to develop into something that is ultimately complex in the end. It is an unforgettable and incredibly well written story full of endearing characters and surprising scenarios. Perhaps this film did not put Mr. Hitchcock on the map (for he was already on it), but it inspired a generation of mystery films to come. And thats good enough for me.

          James Jimmy Stewart puts on yet again a stellar and unforgettable performance. Everything he does (from the way he talks to the way he walks) is so perfect and endearing. His character is always interesting and as an actor hes just plain unpredictable. Its a shame that theres no Jimmy Stewart for the Facebook generation. Sure, we have a crap load of great actors, but what the hell. You simply cannot replace ol Jimmy. Kim Novak is also pitch perfect and rather unpredictable in her role, although not as much as Mr. Stewart. No other man (or woman) in this film can match the awesomeness that he ultimately delivers. Otherwise, a colorful supporting cast also helps these two awesome stars carry the fire until it burns to a coal.

                I must be perfectly clear if I am to tell you just what kind of film Vertigo is. Its a mystery film that is surprisingly complex and has more than its share of surprises. It is meant to shock you with its twist and dazzle you with its visual style. This is indeed a visually impressive achievement from Hitchcock. Its in color, for Christ sake. And it has dazzling cinematography as well. The camera angles are just right, and for the time the texturing was amazing. Now, its not AS dazzling, but it still looks great none the less. I mean, come on. Its Vertigo. The film also makes use of imaginative imagery through dream sequences and the like. These scenes are rare, but in that sense they are treats. The films soundtrack is as awesome as youd hope for it to be, although it would have been perfect only if it were more psychological. None the less, this is an artistic film all around. And it fits the genre quite perfectly. This is indeed a mystery film, and a damn good one by all means. There are not many mystery films that can match an experience as powerful and forceful as this one here. Perhaps it will not be entertaining to everyone, but to most film fanatics it will be fascinating. Nevertheless, I love it because it is an achievement in film and is truly intelligent on all accounts. 

          The meaning of the word vertigo is said to be a certain dizziness of some sort. I guess the films title refers ultimately to the acrophobia of its main character. I find it to be revolutionary none the less. This really is a beautiful film, and I may watch it again. Not because I need to, but because I simply want to experience it all once more before I forget all about it. Chances are, Ill purchase a copy of it and remember it forevermore. You can count on that. So if you have yet to see Vertigo, then I suggest you make it a top priority. It is an event in filmmaking even if it does not rank among my absolute favorites. I love it nevertheless. Who says you cant love something without it being your favorite, am I right? Is it a crime to love a piece of art as it is? No, it isnt. Film lovers rejoice. Hitchcock has again made a movie for all of us. All of us accept for non-film lovers. Theyll probably be bored within the first ten minutes of apparently dated Technicolor. But whatever. I could care less. This is a great film and nobody should deny it. Its simply a matter of personal preference. Thats damn right, my friends. Damn right.

Hitchcock's Vertigo is an indusputable masterpiece that explores the relation between time, memory, and obsession in a twisting, surrealistic story that leaves the viewer experiencing his/her own sense of Vertigo. One of the better known Hitchcock films; it has a long and strenuous history as well as a legacy unlike many of his other films. In part this is probably because Hitchcock made this film very personal, and made it his mission to indelibly link it to himself. The film is based on a book by two of his favorite writers, it takes on a psychological problem among scores of real people, and it has a great twist that makes it iconic. Unlike some of Hitchcock's previous films, this one takes a decidedly mature look at murder. Not that films such as "Rear Window" and "The Man Who Knew Too Much" didn't seem devilish, but there's something so methodically torturous about the psyche of the main character that it makes it stand out from his previous films. "Psycho" would be the only true rival to this film, though this one feels more like a passion project than the former. When this film was initially released it didn't do well with box office figures and certainly not with the critics. Most of the criticism attributed to this film has to do with the choice in cast. James Stewart was a powerful and interesting collaborator with Hitchcock throughout both of their careers, but at the time he was pushing fifty and having a 24 year old love interest (Novak) as the femme fatale seemed a little too overboard for most audiences. This doesn't really bother you as the viewer though, because the character of Judy seems too needy and unloved, so that Scottie's (Stewart) admiration for her only shows her true colors. Scottie loving Madeleine only shows her inherent beauty and youth. Scottie's vertigo isn't used in every juncture of the film, but it is used as a pivotal piece of the plot, and remains one of the better Hitchcockian twists in any film. Everything about this film feels a bit off, mostly because it is dealing with the subject of vertigo, and the strange fascination of two identical people fooling another all for the means of a fiend. Hitchcock is marvelous, and it really pains me to know that this film, sometimes said to be the best film of all time, was reviled when it came out.

Perhaps Hitchcock's most ambitious film and I think the least successful of his " big four" ( Vertigo, Psycho, Rear Window, North by Northwest). Instead of aiming for pure visceral thrills i.e. Psycho or political thriller and nature of innocence i.e. North by Northwest Alfred is interested in tackling the more interesting themes of love, obsession, and death. The mystery plot serves Hitchcock's ideas rather than vice versa, as in his other works. But despite an appropriately haunted performance from James Stewart, and haunting one from Kim Novak, something just does not click. I think Hitchcock is so accustomed to breakneck pace that when attempting to slow it down he cannot hold interest quite so well. The film does however boast one of the most impressive closing sequences in cinema, one that has doubtless been the template for countless mind-bending thrillers, from Memento to the Usual Suspects. Despite being a slightly flawed entry into the Hitchcock Canon Vertigo  is still devilishly intriguing and well worth watching.

Vertigo: "A haunting tale of deception, madness, and death--a masterful exploration of fantasy and anxiety." Oh, but it is quite the contrary! There is nothing haunting about Hitchcock's 'Vertigo', nothing mad. Perhaps it is the test-of-time that haunts this film so, or perhaps my expectations where cast too high, that a fall as hard as mine was a mere inevitability. Or perhaps I have read the pages of too many novels to find the storytelling here nothing more than uninteresting.

James Stewart is an ex-police detective 'Scottie' Ferguson suffering from vertigo who is asked by an old friend to investigate his wife who seems to be behaving rather oddly. Rescuing her when she tries to drown herself in San Francisco Bay, he gets in a bit too deep when he falls for her. Just as their relationship is beginning to blossom, she falls to her death from the top of a bell tower and Ferguson is powerless to stop this as his vertigo prevents him from going up tall buildings. Ferguson becomes a broken man but suddenly a chance encounter on a street 1 year later sees him looking at somebody who seems exactly like the woman he loved. He even begins a relationship with her, becoming obsessed that she should become the same as his old love with the same clothes, mannerisms and hairstyle.

One of Hitchcock's classic movies with James Stewart in one of his best roles as an obsessed driven man who can't let go of the past. Vertigo is a psychological thriller that delivers twists and turns to keep you guessing and intrigued into how everything pans out. A tale of two halfs with the first focusing on a mystery whilst the second takes a turn into the dark side about obsession and the mindset of a psychologically battered man. The alluring Kim Novak is also excellent in her dual role as a tool designed to ensnare Ferguson into a wider plot. Film noir at it's finest.

I've never known what to expect from Vertigo, and knew absolutely nothing of it's subject matter. During the first hour or so, all I could think was "Wow, THIS is what this movie is about? THIS is it?" -- any expectations that I had (unformed as they may have been) were completely violated, and I was somewhat disappointed. I thought it was just another case of the hype being greater than the film. But then, just when I was expecting absolutely nothing more to come from this mild let-down of a classic-film viewing experience, the weird cartoon/color-flashing "dream sequence" started, and everything clicked -- I realized why what I had been watching actually was, in many ways, a movie that practically had my name written all over it. Hitchcock's masterpiece actually reminds of everything that I love about Roman Polanski's work -- it's disturbing, twisted, emotional, daring, and, of course, related to identity and obsession. Jimmy Stewart and (especially) Kim Novak are fantastic in the leads, and the film just gets better with every second, leading up to it's dark and ambiguous ending. It's safe to say Vertigo is now one of my absolute favorite films, and I can't wait to watch it again and again.

Vertigo, Great Movies
One of the many things that made Hitchcock such a great director is that he did not just stick to the same formula time after time; all of his best movies have their own unique feel and characteristics. "Vertigo" is particularly distinctive, both as a complex story filled with suspense, and as a fascinating study in psychological tension. While it lacks the humor of some of Hitchcock's other masterpieces, and sometimes moves rather slowly, it is unforgettable, and a great achievement by the director and his cast.
If you have never seen it, you will enjoy it more if you do not know too much about the plot, although the actual story is somewhat secondary to the ways that the characters are tested and their weaknesses exposed by the various events. Hitchcock uses a complicated story, interesting characters, lavish visual detail, and deliberate pacing, plus a fine musical score by the incomparable Bernard Hermann, to produce a mysterious, almost unearthly, atmosphere. The tension rarely lets up, and the viewer is caught up completely in it, at times almost to the point of discomfort. It's the kind of film that repays careful attention, as almost every moment is filled with significant detail.
There are also some great acting performances. Jimmy Stewart is outstanding in a role far different from his usual screen persona. He enables the viewer to sympathize completely with him, even as we cringe at many of his character's actions and decisions. Kim Novak is completely convincing in a difficult dual role, and the movie would not have been as compelling without her fine performance. The rest of the cast all have much smaller roles, but are all quite good too, especially Barbara Bel Geddes as Scottie's (Stewart's) old friend, who provides important insight into Scottie's character.
"Vertigo" is a classic by any standard. It's a must-see that remains just as impressive with each viewing.
